Description: Egyptian terracotta female figure with her hair partially concealed by veil and headdress. Head only. Mould-made and hollow. Traces of white coating. Dark red-brown Nile silt fabric with grey core. Abundant fine gold mica, quartz and white inclusions.
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by the Museum of Classical Archaeology, Cambridge. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.

Probably locally produced at the Naukratis terracottas workshop that was operational between the 3rd to the 2nd century BC. Gutch dates this example to 150BC-250AD (Hogarth 1899, pl. 12.163). Hogarth, D. G., Edgar, C.C. 1899, “Excavations at Naukratis”, ABSA 5, 26-46.
Bibliographic references: Gutch 1898/1899 / Excavations at Naukratis, D. The Terracottas (p. 91, no. 163, pl. XII, no.163)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (DD.459) (Phase 1)
